Definition: The lowest price a seller is willing to accept for a security.
A market in which buyers enter competitive bids and sellers enter competitive offers simultaneously.
The maximum number of shares a corporation is legally permitted to issue.
The average number of shares traded per day over a specified period.
The administrative area of a financial institution that supports trading, settlements, and record-keeping.
The interest rate at which a nation's central bank lends money to domestic banks.
A set of agreements by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision providing recommendations on banking laws and regulations.
The highest price a buyer is willing to pay for a security.
The difference between the bid price and the ask price of a security.
A large, privately negotiated securities transaction.
Shares of a nationally recognized, financially sound, and well-established company.
A firm in the business of buying and selling securities for its own account or on behalf of customers.
Physical gold or silver in the form of bars, ingots, or coins.
A bond that can be redeemed by the issuer before its maturity date.
A measure of a bank's capital, expressed as a percentage of its risk-weighted credit exposures.
The national institution that manages a country's currency, money supply, and interest rates.
An intermediary between buyers and sellers of financial instruments that ensures the proper settlement of trades.
The final price of a security at the end of a trading session.
A financial institution that accepts deposits, offers checking accounts, and makes loans.
A bond that can be converted into a predetermined number of the issuing company's shares.
The annual interest rate paid on a bond, expressed as a percentage of its face value.
An options strategy where an investor holds a long position in an asset and sells call options on that same asset.
A financial institution responsible for safeguarding a firm's or individual's financial assets.
The buying and selling of securities within the same trading day.
A negotiable financial instrument representing a foreign company's publicly traded securities.
A market where financial instruments like futures, options, and swaps are traded.
A bond sold for less than its face value.
An index of 30 major publicly traded companies in the U.S.
Shares that give different voting rights and dividend payments to different classes of shareholders.
A computerized system that facilitates trading of financial products outside traditional exchanges.
An economy that is progressing toward becoming more advanced, often through rapid growth and industrialization.
A bond issued in a currency not native to the country where it is issued.
A marketplace where securities, commodities, derivatives, and other instruments are traded.
The completion of a buy or sell order in the market.
The interest rate at which U.S. banks lend balances to each other overnight.
A marketplace where buyers and sellers trade financial assets such as stocks, bonds, derivatives, and currencies.
A customized contract between two parties to buy or sell an asset at a specified future date for a price agreed upon today.
The division of a financial institution responsible for sales, trading, and other revenue-generating activities.
High-grade bonds issued by certain national governments.
A bank certificate issued in more than one country for shares in a foreign company.
A debt security issued by a government to support spending.
A type of algorithmic trading that uses powerful computers to transact large numbers of orders at extremely high speeds.
An acquisition attempt by a company that is strongly resisted by the target company’s management.
The percentage of the purchase price of securities that an investor must pay for with their own cash or marginable securities.
The global network used by financial institutions to trade currencies among themselves.
An international organization established to promote global monetary cooperation and stability.
A financial institution that helps companies raise capital and provides advisory services on mergers and acquisitions.
An entity that develops, registers, and sells securities to finance its operations.
A high-yield, high-risk security typically issued by companies seeking to raise capital quickly.
The London Interbank Offered Rate, formerly the benchmark interest rate at which major global banks lent to one another.
An order to buy or sell a security at a specified price or better.
A measure of a company’s ability to pay off its short-term liabilities with its current assets.
A stock, bond, or other security that is traded on an organized exchange.
The process of involving multiple lenders in funding portions of a loan for a single borrower.
The purchase of a security with the expectation that it will rise in value.
A firm or individual that actively quotes two-sided markets in a financial instrument, providing bids and offers.
An order to buy or sell a stock immediately at the best available price.
Any individual or institution that is actively involved in buying or selling financial instruments.
The possibility of an investor experiencing losses due to factors that affect the overall performance of the financial markets.
The date on which the principal amount of a bond or other debt instrument becomes due and payable.
A financial institution that provides capital to companies in the form of share ownership.
The total amount of money in circulation or in existence in an economy at a given time.
A global electronic marketplace for buying and selling securities, as well as the benchmark index for U.S. technology stocks.
A performance metric that examines how successful a firm’s investment decisions are compared to its debt situations.
The New York Stock Exchange, the world's largest equities-based exchange.
The total number of outstanding derivative contracts, such as options or futures, that have not been settled.
A listing of all available option contracts for a given security.
A condition in which the price of a security has risen too far, too fast, and is likely due for a correction.
A condition in which the price of a security has fallen too far, too fast, and is likely due for a rebound.
A stock that trades at a relatively low price, often outside of major market exchanges.
A person or team responsible for making investment decisions for a fund or client portfolio.
The market where new securities are issued and sold to investors for the first time.
The original amount of money borrowed in a loan or put into an investment.
A monetary policy used by central banks to stimulate the economy by buying financial assets.
The last price at which a security or commodity traded, or the most recent bid and ask prices.
A form of short-term borrowing for dealers in government securities.
The identification, analysis, and mitigation of uncertainty in investment decisions.
A marketplace where investors buy and sell securities they already own.
The U.S. federal agency that regulates the securities markets and protects investors.
The date on which a trade is finalized and securities are delivered to the buyer while cash is paid to the seller.
The sale of a security not owned by the seller, with the expectation it will decline in value.
The difference between two prices, rates, or yields.
A measurement of the performance of a group of stocks that represent a particular market or sector.
An order to buy or sell a security once its price reaches a specified level.
An option granting the right but not the obligation to enter into a swap agreement by a specified date.
The risk of collapse of an entire financial system or entire market.
An abbreviation used to uniquely identify publicly traded shares of a particular stock.
The process of transferring securities to the buyer and payment to the seller after a trade has been executed.
A marketable U.S. government debt security with a fixed interest rate and maturity between one and ten years.
The process by which an investment bank raises investment capital from investors on behalf of corporations and governments issuing securities.
A federal regulation that restricts U.S. banks from making certain types of speculative investments.
The number of shares or contracts traded in a security or market during a given period.
A line that plots interest rates of bonds having equal credit quality but differing maturity dates.
A bank with an economic net worth less than zero that continues to operate due to government support.
